issue.title: Use OpenSSL's EVP_MD_CTX_new and _free
issue.body:
Fixes #565.

Does so by requiring OpenSSL version 1.1.0 or higher.  But one of our target platforms (Ubuntu Xenial 16.04) only comes with OpenSSL 1.0.2.  So what should we do?  Require users on that platform to build OpenSSL 1.0.2 (and update our Docker images accordingly)?  Or remove that as a target platform?  Thoughts, @baentsch and @xvzcf?

comment.body:
I'd vote for removing support for Ubuntu 16 and providing documentation how someone can help himself if he's "bound" to it (build OpenSSL 1.1.1 from source first). The same is true for OSX, if I'm not mistaken: Default OpenSSL is 1.0.2 and you have to brew install 1.1.1 first before working with OQS-OpenSSL. 

I'm not sure how a Docker image update can help, though: Which image do you suggest updating in which way? If you think about the dev image, I'm not sure that would solve a user's issue: They then may have a ready-made build environment, but I don't think they would keep working in it (for their "main project" that "keeps them bound" to Ubuntu 16).

Net-net: I'd remove support for Xenial, document as suggested above and wait whether there's howls of protest.

issue.title: KEMS can now be built using CMake.
issue.body:
## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To build on Windows: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -G "NMake Makefiles" .. && nmake"` in the VS Developer console. Alternatively, just running `cmake ..` will generate build files for Visual Studio.

To build shared libraries: `cmake -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -GNinja ..`
To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`
To disable (for example) all SPHINCS variants, pass `-DENABLE_SIG_SPHINCS=OFF`

To run all the tests, invoke `ninja run_tests`
To build documentation, invoke `ninja gen_docs`

## Things left to do:

1) Add all compilation flags after SIKE warnings are dealt with.
2) Add CMake and ninja to CI environments and update the build scripts accordingly.
3) Add the `copy_from_pqclean` templating.
4) Update README.

comment.body: Really nice. Tested both on Ubuntu and OSX. No comments beyond those already made. Would love to use it to build shared libs (but indeed only after the warnings are dealt with: They make one nervous :-).

issue.title: BIKE code failing on AVX512f

comment.body:
> Another build failure as well in https://circleci.com/gh/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/3189:

This one is unrelated to AVX512f and could be fixed by making `rotate256_big` static.

issue.title: Use OpenSSL's EVP_MD_CTX_new and _free
issue.body:
Fixes #565.

Does so by requiring OpenSSL version 1.1.0 or higher.  But one of our target platforms (Ubuntu Xenial 16.04) only comes with OpenSSL 1.0.2.  So what should we do?  Require users on that platform to build OpenSSL 1.0.2 (and update our Docker images accordingly)?  Or remove that as a target platform?  Thoughts, @baentsch and @xvzcf?

comment.body:
> The same is true for OSX, if I'm not mistaken: Default OpenSSL is 1.0.2 and you have to brew install 1.1.1 first before working with OQS-OpenSSL.

Yes, I modified the instructions to require `brew install openssl@1.1` and `./configure` looks in the place that brew would put it.

> I'm not sure how a Docker image update can help, though: Which image do you suggest updating in which way? 

I was meaning installing OpenSSL in our Xenial image.

> Net-net: I'd remove support for Xenial, document as suggested above and wait whether there's howls of protest.

Fine with me.  Let's give it a couple of days on here for any such preliminary howls.

issue.title: Standardization of the dynamic library names so that Mac and Linux could be supported
issue.body:
The current C library wrapper is set to build with liboqs.dll, oqs.so and oqs.dylib respectively.
In order to support Mac and Linux, the file name has to be the same.

Which would be more preferred name to standardize the C# wrapper codes?
"liboqs" or "oqs"

comment.body: If the DLL on the Windows version was called liboqs.dll, and you change DllImport to "liboqs" without the file extension, would that make everything happy?  As for platform conventions, is it okay to have "lib" at the beginning of a DLL's filename?

issue.title: Partial fix for failing BIKE code
issue.body: Partial fix to #590 as suggested by @franziskuskiefer in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/590#issuecomment-577667909.

issue.title: BIKE code failing on AVX512f
Use OpenSSL's EVP_MD_CTX_new and _free
issue.body:
Fixes #565.

Does so by requiring OpenSSL version 1.1.0 or higher.  But one of our target platforms (Ubuntu Xenial 16.04) only comes with OpenSSL 1.0.2.  So what should we do?  Require users on that platform to build OpenSSL 1.0.2 (and update our Docker images accordingly)?  Or remove that as a target platform?  Thoughts, @baentsch and @xvzcf?

comment.body: I agree with @baentsch; we could have suggestions/instructions for upgrading to 1.1.1, but we shouldn't worry about support for 1.0.2.

issue.title: Standardization of the dynamic library names so that Mac and Linux could be supported
issue.body:
The current C library wrapper is set to build with liboqs.dll, oqs.so and oqs.dylib respectively.
In order to support Mac and Linux, the file name has to be the same.

Which would be more preferred name to standardize the C# wrapper codes?
"liboqs" or "oqs"

comment.body:
As we discussed on issue #2, @jianmingyong, we are interested in supporting Linux and Mac. It looks like you are on your way of testing that, so any shareable code (that you can submit as a PR) would be interesting to see. Is this naming issue the only problem blocking Linux/Mac, or are there more steps?

Prepending "lib" in front of Windows DLLs is not common, @dstebila; if we choose to do that to simplify this project, then we would need to make sure there are no side effects for the Windows build of our OpenSSL and OpenSSH forks.

## Build Instructions

To build on UNIX-y systems: `mkdir build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

To use (or not use) OpenSSL, pass `-DUSE_OPENSSL={ON|OFF}`

issue.title: Use OpenSSL's EVP_MD_CTX_new and _free
issue.body:
Fixes #565.

Does so by requiring OpenSSL version 1.1.0 or higher.  But one of our target platforms (Ubuntu Xenial 16.04) only comes with OpenSSL 1.0.2.  So what should we do?  Require users on that platform to build OpenSSL 1.0.2 (and update our Docker images accordingly)?  Or remove that as a target platform?  Thoughts, @baentsch and @xvzcf?

comment.body: Xenial is currently where we do all our testing of old versions of gcc, so if we want to keep testing how this compiles under old versions of gcc, we'd have to move those tests over to another image, e.g., Ubuntu bionic. Any thoughts on how many versions of gcc back we should go?

issue.title: New Docker images
issue.body: As per the discussion regarding Docker images this is a 'clean' PR only comprising only Alpine, Centos7&8, Ubuntu-18 image-build instructions in line with what is discussed [here](https://github.com/baentsch/testing/wiki/Docker-image-goals) and may be easier to merge in. As such this may supersede the other PR's in this repo. Let's agree on Wed, Jan 15 (what to keep and what to prune in this repo). This code also is the base for [this PR](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/581) in `liboqs`.

comment.body:
I've moved the new CI environments to https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/testing/pull/37, where I also removed all the integration tests from this repository. 

I will also open a PR in the OpenSSL and OpenSSH repositories to propagate the changes made in this PR to the integration tests.

issue.title: Standardization of the dynamic library names so that Mac and Linux could be supported
issue.body:
The current C library wrapper is set to build with liboqs.dll, oqs.so and oqs.dylib respectively.
In order to support Mac and Linux, the file name has to be the same.

Which would be more preferred name to standardize the C# wrapper codes?
"liboqs" or "oqs"

comment.body:
@christianpaquin Naming the file does make it simple by just removing the dll import file extension. After that it works like a charm.

I understand the concern for other project that might have used the current file naming convention causing unintended side effects. If the OpenSSL and OpenSSH forks used file name to detect the library, it would have been a breaking change.

In that case, it is safe to assume it would be better to have the current file names. I should be able to cook up a PR for that. It results in slightly longer code for the same API but it can ensure compatibility is preserve for both file names.

I will close this first and work on the required change.
